MainClaim.text: "Descartes's moral thought forms a surprisingly unified whole

VirtueIsSufficientForHappiness.text: "Descartes claims that virtue is sufficient for happiness

sAccountOfVirtue.text: "Descartes's account of virtue consists of two features: judging well and striving to act according to one's judgment."

TwoComponentTheoryOfMoralAction.text: "Descartes's account of moral agency consists of two components: the cognitive component of judging well and the conative component of striving to act according to one's judgment."

VirtueEqualsJudgingWell.text: "Virtue equals acting in accordance with the two-component theory of moral agency."

sAccountOfHappiness.text: "Descartes's account of happiness is about having a contented mind."

IntellectualInsight.text: "An intellectual insight consisting of three key components is necessary to secure happiness."

DescartesLeavesPremiseImplicit.text: "Descartes leaves the intellectual insight necessary for happiness implicit because it appears much more self-evident to him than to us."

VirtueEqualsConativeComponent.text: "Virtue is primarily about exerting ourselves according to our best judgment."

DescartesDownplaysIntellectualInsight.text: "Descartes downplays the intellectual insight his account involves because he thinks that all of its three main components are innocuous in their ubiquity."

PremiseIsImplicitBecauseSelfEvident.text: "The intellectual insight necessary for happiness is implicit because its components are so evident that little reflection is needed to realize them."

CartesianSageIsSimilarToStoicSage.text: "The Cartesian sage is similar to the Stoic sage in that both are concerned with governing their desires and taking a clear conscience as the goal of their actions."

StoicismAndCartesianism.text: "Descartes's theory of the passions shows that he was concerned with the same issues as the Stoics
